title: Can I get UFO records through the Freedom of Information Act? Ask the lawyer
description: Ask the Lawyer columnist Ron Sokol discusses the federal Freedom of Information Act and the California Public Records Act.
article_content:
Q: We are seeking records on UFOs, and were told to try the Freedom of Information Act. First question, can you explain the Freedom of Information Act? Then, how do we go about requesting records?

J.V., Glendale

A: The Freedom of Information Act (abbreviated as FOIA) provides you with the right to request access to records of the executive branch of the United States government. The records are to be provided, unless they are subject to certain exemptions whose purpose is to protect disclosure deemed harmful to: (a) national security, (b) privacy of individuals, (c) proprietary business information (such as trade secrets), (d) the actual functioning of our government, and/or (e) other interests that are deemed of significant importance. The exemptions are real, but FOIA requests often are productive.

The act dates from 1967 and took many years to become law. The objective is to make our government more transparent. As to UFOs (which the government now refers to as “unidentified anomalous phenomena”), federal agencies have been required this year to organize and tag documents. Congress has expressed clear interest in determining what agencies know about UFOs. Thus, the agencies are to disclose their information by the end of this fiscal year. The records are also to be housed at the National Archives and Records Administration.

Here, then, is an outline of a FOIA request you can consider: Using letterhead, set forth the date you are sending it; then list the name and address of the executive agency where the request is being sent; then “RE: FOIA REQUEST”; followed by “Dear Sir or Madam: This is an authorized request to you under the Freedom of Information Act. Please provide the following records to the undersigned on a timely basis. …” Here, clearly set forth the records sought, describing them, if possible, by year(s), name of the party or parties involved, and/or the circumstances or events in focus. Then close the FOIA request with a sign off.

Note that some agencies have instructions on where a FOIA request is to be sent (you can look for that online, or call to inquire). While it is not required that the FOIA request be transmitted by certified mail/return receipt requested, doing so is one way to seek to show that you not only sent it, but that it was received. The agency is required to respond within 20 working days (excluding weekends and legal holidays).

Q: There was a local incident that at first was well reported. An older person was run over by a hit-and-run driver. We think they have since found the identity of the driver, who may be a local official, but there is radio silence. Our neighbor suggests we try a Public Records Act request. Can you give us some guidance on that?

M.B., (location withheld)

Related Articles News | Am I liable for a slip and fall at a bowling alley? Ask the lawyer

Am I liable for a slip and fall at a bowling alley? Ask the lawyer News | Who regulates our national parks? Ask the lawyer

Who regulates our national parks? Ask the lawyer News | What is a liquor license and how do I obtain one? Ask the lawyer

What is a liquor license and how do I obtain one? Ask the lawyer News | How can we collect the judgment? Ask the lawyer

How can we collect the judgment? Ask the lawyer News | Can someone become president for life? Ask the lawyer A: The Public Records Act is found at California Government Code Sections 6250 through 6277. The act gives you, as a member of the public, the right to request information from California governmental agencies, which includes both state and local/municipal governments. In some instances, you may be able to learn online or by phone where to send the request, depending on which agency the request is going to (such as, the police department, highway patrol, zoning commission, district attorney’s office or mayor’s office, among others). As with a FOIA request, be specific about what you are seeking, and to whom and where the records are to be sent. The agency has 10 calendar days to respond to you, but may indicate it needs more time to locate, review and produce the records (which can mean a 14-day extension for “unusual circumstances”).

As with a FOIA request, some records may be deemed confidential or otherwise off-limits.

A Public Records Act request, however, should not be costly or time consuming. It is the law, and compliance is expected to the extent authorized and permissible. I cannot say the request will unveil what you are looking for, and records you get may have redactions (which the agency can seek to justify), but, as they say, “nothing ventured, nothing gained.”

Ron Sokol has been a practicing attorney for over 40 years, and has also served many times as a judge pro tem, mediator, and arbitrator. It is important to keep in mind that this column presents a summary of the law, and is not to be treated or considered legal advice, let alone a substitute for actual consultation with a qualified professional.

description: "I would go to jail to say things that I've been exposed to in the program." 🛸 What is really out there? Lab 9 Films has ...
article_content:
Official Trailer for 'The Program' - Yet Another New UFO Documentary

"I would go to jail to say things that I've been exposed to in the program." 🛸 What is really out there? Lab 9 Films has revealed an official trailer for yet another new documentary about UFOs – this one called The Program. Ever since the US government started actually talking openly about UFOs, now officially known as UAP ("Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena") sightings, Ufologists have been going crazy. They've gone beyond conspiracy drifting into full-on "it has to be true!" irrefutable belief. Of course. The Program is yet another new UFOs / aliens-are-real film from filmmaker James Fox, who also made The Phenomenon and Moment of Contact in the years before. Featuring narration by Peter Coyote (Bitter Moon, E.T.). The doc includes "extensive interviews with insiders, experts and politicians. Christopher Mellon, the former deputy assistant secretary of defense for intelligence, and Stanford University's Dr. Gary Nolan, [are] among those who appear in the doc." It's another doc about extraterrestrials that now wants to dig into the question: is there a big government program keeping the truth a secret? (Is it called The X-Files?) What do you believe?

Here's the official trailer (+ poster) for James Fox's UFO doc The Program, direct from YouTube:

This highly anticipated follow-up to director James Fox's other blockbuster UFO documentary films, The Phenomenon (2020) and Moment of Contact (2022), The Program explores the unprecedented bipartisan Congressional effort to uncover what US intelligence agencies really know about UFOs, now referred to as UAP. The first two public hearings in over half a century included testimony under oath from military & intelligence officers with jaw-dropping allegations of a clandestine program to analyze materials and non-human biologics. Through candid interviews with high-ranking insiders, elected officials, physicists, intelligence officers, and military whistleblowers, The Program goes behind the scenes to leave even the staunchest skeptics astounded by the assertions from a growing chorus of insiders that we are not alone. The Program is directed by ufologist / filmmaker James Fox, director of the other doc films I Know What I Saw, The Phenomenon, and Moment of Contact previously. Produced by James Fox & Lance Mungia. Lab 9 Films releases Fox's doc The Program in select US theaters + on VOD to watch later in 2024. Stay tuned.

title: OpenAI's DevDay brings Realtime API and other treats for AI app developers
description: It's been a tumultuous week for OpenAI, full of executive departures and major fundraising developments, but the startup is ...
article_content:
It's been a tumultuous week for OpenAI, full of executive departures and major fundraising developments, but the startup is back at it, trying to convince developers to build tools with its AI models at its 2024 DevDay. The company announced several new tools Tuesday, including a public beta of its "Realtime API", for building apps with low-latency, AI-generated voice responses. It's not quite ChatGPT's Advanced Voice Mode, but it's close.

In a briefing with reporters ahead of the event, OpenAI chief product officer Kevin Weil said the recent departures of chief technology officer Mira Murati and chief research officer Bob McGrew would not affect the company's progress.

"I'll start with saying Bob and Mira have been awesome leaders. I've learned a lot from them, and they are a huge part of getting us to where we are today," said Weil. "And also, we're not going to slow down."

As OpenAI undergoes yet another C-suite overhaul – a reminder of the turmoil following last year's DevDay – the company is trying to convince developers that it still offers the best platform to build AI apps on. Leaders say the startup has more than 3 million developers building with its AI models, but OpenAI is operating in an increasingly competitive space.

OpenAI noted it had cut costs for developers to access its API by 99% in the last two years, though it was likely forced to by competitors such as Meta and Google continuously undercutting their prices.

One of OpenAI's new features, dubbed the Realtime API, will give developers the chance to build nearly real-time, speech-to-speech experiences in their apps, with the choice of using six voices provided by OpenAI. These voices are distinct from those offered for ChatGPT, and developers can't use third party voices, in order to prevent copyright issues. (The voice ambiguously based on Scarlett Johansson's is not available anywhere.)

During the briefing, OpenAI's head of developer experience, Romain Huet, shared a demo of a trip planning app built with the Realtime API. The application allowed users to verbally speak with an AI assistant about an upcoming trip to London, and get low-latency responses. The Realtime API also has access to a number of tools, so the app was able to annotate a map with restaurant locations as it answered.

At another point, Huet showed how the Realtime API could speak on the phone with a human to inquire about ordering food for an event. Unlike Google's infamous Duo, OpenAI's API can't call restaurants or shops directly; however, it can integrate with calling APIs like Twilio to do so. Notably, OpenAI is not adding disclosures so that its AI models automatically identify themselves on calls like this, despite the fact that these AI-generated voices sounds quite realistic. For now, it seems to be the developers' responsibility to add this disclosure, something that could be required by a new California law.

As part of its DevDay announcements, OpenAI also introduced vision fine-tuning in its API, which will let developers use images, as well as text, to fine-tune their applications of GPT-4o. This should, in theory, help developers improve the performance of GPT-4o for tasks involving visual understanding. OpenAI's head of product API, Olivier Godement, tells TechCrunch that developers will not be able to upload copyrighted imagery (such as a picture of Donald Duck), images that depict violence, or other imagery that violates OpenAI's safety policies.

OpenAI is racing to match what its competitors in the AI model licensing space already offer. Its prompt caching feature is similar to the feature Anthropic launched several months agoallowing developers to cache frequently used context between API calls, reducing costs and improve latency. OpenAI says developers can save 50% using this feature, whereas Anthropic promises a 90% discount for it.

Lastly, OpenAI is offering a model distillation feature to let developers use larger AI models, such as o1-preview and GPT-4o, to fine-tune smaller models such as GPT-4o mini. Running smaller models generally provides cost savings compare to running larger ones, but this feature should let developers improve the performance of those small AI models. As part of model distillation, OpenAI is launching a beta evaluation tool so developers can measure their fine-tune's performance within OpenAI's API.

DevDay may make bigger waves for what it didn't announce – for instance, there wasn't any news on the GPT Store announced during last year's DevDay. Last we've heard, OpenAI has been piloting a revenue share program with some of the most popular creators of GPTs, but the company hasn't announced much since then.

Also, OpenAI says it's not releasing any new AI models during DevDay this year. Developers waiting for OpenAI o1 (not the preview or mini version) or the startup's video generation model, Sora, will have to wait a little longer.

title: OpenAI wants all your apps to talk in its expressive AI voices
description: OpenAI will let businesses use the latest voice technology in ChatGPT inside their own products, potentially expanding the ...
article_content:
SAN FRANCISCO — ChatGPT maker OpenAI will allow any app developer to add snappy and humanlike voice interaction to their products, a move that could greatly increase the number of people interacting with a slick and sometimes provocative new generation of artificial intelligence technology. OpenAI’s “advanced voice mode,” which offers six AI voices that sound casual and expressive, with the ability to detect and react to different human vocal tones, has been available to ChatGPT subscribers since July. The technology will now be offered to the thousands of companies that pay to use OpenAI technology in their own products — and any new developer who signs up.

Opening more of its AI inventions to outsiders could help grow OpenAI’s revenue from usage fees it charges each time an app taps its technology. Increasing that income is crucial to the company, which is seeking billions of dollars in new funding and considering restructuring to remove its business from the control of its existing nonprofit board.

Advertisement

OpenAI announced it was opening access to its voice technology at an event in San Francisco for software developers. At a news briefing ahead of the event, OpenAI executives showed how an app built on its voice technology could make a phone call to a business and place an order for chocolate strawberries.

The business was not real and the person who took down the order and asked questions that the AI voice nimbly responded to was an OpenAI executive role-playing, but app developers will be able to deploy that capability immediately, the executives said.

“We want to make it possible to interact with AI in all of the ways you interact with a human being,” OpenAI chief product officer Kevin Weil said at the press briefing.

Fully achieving that goal would be challenging with existing AI technology, which often makes mistakes. But if app developers rush to build on OpenAI’s voice algorithms many more people could soon be using or exposed to automated systems that capably mimic people in some scenarios.

Advertisement

Realistic voice synthesis technology has already been used in some call centers but if OpenAI succeeds in making it more sophisticated and widespread, then consumers could encounter fresh frustrations or scams as well as new conveniences.

The Federal Communications Commission last week fined a political consultant $6 million for using AI to fake the voice of President Joe Biden in New Hampshire robocalls earlier this year.

In 2018, Google debuted its AI voice bot, Google Duplex, that could call restaurants or salons to make reservations. But the humans employed by local businesses receiving the calls didn’t always like it.

Initially, Duplex did not disclose that it was a piece of software, until the backlash prompted Google to reprogram it to always introduce itself as an AI system. The feature hasn’t caught on broadly, although Google Pixel phones can screen calls using similar technology and the company’s cloud unit offers voice technology for call centers.

Advertisement

Voice bots have drastically improved over the past several years, with OpenAI’s new voice mode for ChatGPT winning plaudits for its ability to carry out snappy conversations, understand complex topics and questions, sing and respond to different tones of voice when it was first unveiled in May.

OpenAI’s system has been tuned to sound eager and polite, similar to the tone of ChatGPT’s textual answers. The company offers six voices to choose from but retired its initial default, called “Sky,” after Scarlett Johansson alleged the company copied her voice without permission. Documents shared with The Washington Post indicate a different actor was hired for recordings used to make the voice.

OpenAI says 3 million developers in dozens of countries are now experimenting with its technology and using it to build new apps and features. Opening up its latest voice features could help grow that crucial user base and the revenue it provides.

Advertisement

Some tech investors and entrepreneurs say that just like the internet incubated giants like Google and smartphones enabled businesses like Uber and DoorDash, artificial intelligence will also spawn a wave of start-ups that become integral to peoples’ lives.

Other AI experts caution that new capabilities like convincingly expressive voices can cause havoc in the wrong hands. An AI narration service marketed for audiobooks and video games was adapted to make the fake Biden robocalls placed in New Hampshire in January.

OpenAI says its rules ban developers from using its services to spam, mislead or harm people, and that it has built systems that monitor how people use its technology to shut down any who don’t comply.

Developers tapping the new voice offering must “make it clear to their users that they are interacting with AI, unless it’s obvious from the context,” the company said in a blog post about the new tools.

Advertisement

OpenAI’s systems have been abused in the past, despite similar rules being in place for ChatGPT and its other services, including a ban on political campaigning.

title: Perplexity set to release Mac app on Oct 15, competing with OpenAI’s ChatGPT in AI search
description: Perplexity will launch its Mac app on October 15, featuring a pre-order option. The app offers functionalities similar to its ...
article_content:
Perplexity is set to unveil its native Mac application on October 15. A dedicated landing page has appeared on the Mac App Store, offering details about the upcoming release and the features users can expect. As part of this launch, the company is also introducing Perplexity Pro, a premium subscription option that can be purchased through iTunes, aiming to position itself against competitors like OpenAI, which launched its ChatGPT app for Mac earlier this year.

According to the Mac App Store listing, users can pre-order the Perplexity app, which will automatically install on their devices once it becomes available, provided they are connected to the Internet. This pre-order feature functions similarly to pre-installation processes seen on Android platforms.

The Perplexity Mac app promises to deliver all the functionalities available on its web, Android, and iOS versions. Users can enter queries, allowing the AI to sift through online resources to gather information. The app will present results in both bullet-point and paragraph formats, complete with citations to enable users to explore topics further and validate information. Additionally, users will be able to pose follow-up questions, with the AI capable of understanding context to deliver relevant answers. A curated Discover page will also be available to help users uncover new subjects to explore.

Earlier this year, Perplexity launched a Pro Search feature, which leverages advanced inference techniques for in-depth analysis of search queries, particularly beneficial for niche or specialized topics. This feature will be included in the Mac app. On the free tier, users are limited to five searches every four hours.

The app's size is listed at 46.8MB and is compatible with macOS 13 or later. While the app is free to download, the Perplexity Pro subscription provides users with over 300 Pro Search queries daily, complimentary upgrades to the latest AI models, and early access to new features. The monthly subscription is priced at Rs. 1,950, and Mac users can subscribe through iTunes.

title: Win prizes for visiting West Virginia’s paranormal landmarks
description: The West Virginia Department of Tourism is incentivizing paranormal fans to visit the state’s spookiest spots.
article_content:
CLARKSBURG, W.Va. (WBOY) — The West Virginia Department of Tourism is incentivizing paranormal fans to visit the state’s spookiest spots.

Much like the West Virginia Waterfall Trail and West Virginia Culinary Trail, the West Virginia Paranormal Trail offers prizes for checking in at haunted locations across the state. West Virginia residents or tourists can sign up for free and add the experience to their smartphone. From there, all participants have to do is go to one of the 14 spooky locations included and “check in.”

Check in at three locations and get a Paranormal Trail sticker; check in at 10 locations and get a Paranormal Trail beanie; and check in at all the spooky locations and receive a limited edition Paranormal Trail print.

title: How This Remote Utah Ranch Became a Paranormal Activity Hotspot
description: Strange phenomena have lured real-estate tycoons, scientists, TV producers—and the U.S. government—to Skinwalker Ranch. What ...
article_content:
I have been warned. This much is clear within minutes of ducking out of a helicopter onto the high-desert oasis of Skinwalker Ranch in northeastern Utah one searingly bright October afternoon. As a visitor approaching the dark and inscrutable paranormal forces patrolling this property, I could be targeted.

The admonition has come in several forms. There was the prayer for safe deliverance given by chopper pilot Cameron Fugal, brother of property owner Brandon Fugal, as we approached the ranch. This didn’t necessarily rattle me, as I’d recently watched Cameron deliver a similar invocation on season one of The Secret of Skinwalker Ranch, the hit History channel show that has generated mainstream attention for the property.

There was the surreal experience of being greeted on the helipad by about half the show’s cast, whom I felt I’d come to know during my hours of binge watching—standing stone-faced and shoulder to shoulder like some official tribunal ready to deliver grim news. Long-suffering ranch superintendent Thomas Winterton, looking typically Marlboro Man, shook my hand first, followed by glowering security chief Bryant “Dragon” Arnold. Erik Bard, the spritely scientist, and red-bearded security man Kaleb Bench chatted nearby. It was as if my arrival was the only thing holding up the start of the season five shoot. When we go inside, Winterton presents me with a liability waiver, which strikes me as highly unusual—there’s nothing on the day’s agenda beyond an in-depth conversation.

But what truly tweaked my antennae was a conversation I’d had an hour earlier, at the Fugals’ hangar in Provo. Brandon was on the phone, tending to his day job as a commercial real-estate titan, and Cameron and I were chatting amiably when he suddenly pivoted from a story about becoming a grandfather. “Every time we bring somebody new, the ranch interacts a little different,” he said. “Usually it’s been mostly mild. I wouldn’t worry about it too much.” This struck me as a roundabout way of saying I should at least be a little worried.



“We’ve had some guys that are like, ‘This is so stupid—we’re gonna show those aliens who’s boss…’” he continued. “And it’s messed with them.”

“What happened to those guys?” I asked. “Something physical, or their cell phones wigged out, or—?”

It was indeed bodily harm, Cameron said. The previous owner, Robert Bigelow, was haunted by the place, both during his time there and after, when “all the negativity followed him home,” Cameron explained. This sounded a little like the aftermath of a bad Red Lobster meal, but I’d seen the entire series at that point, and I knew what he meant. I’d just never thought of it happening to me.

During the flight, as Brandon recounted the particulars of acquiring the 512-acre ranch, I mentally rifled through the catalog of hazards the show has intimated: unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP, which is the modern term for UFO); cryptic messages transmitted through sound waves or electromagnetic interference; and, possibly most relevant, those weird injuries, including vertigo, nausea, temporary paralysis, hearing impairment, and disorientation, some of which led to hospitalizations.

Shortly after we arrive, I inquire about the ranch’s tendency to identify and punish skeptics. The crew immediately warms to the topic. The visitors with the most serious health effects, Winterton says, “are the ones that came—myself included—with kind of a cavalier attitude of, ‘There’s nothing here that’s gonna bother me.’”

It’s possible the group has inferred a certain skepticism from my request, a few weeks earlier, to camp overnight at the ranch—an inquiry that Fugal shot down, citing liability and safety reasons. Can the capricious forces patrolling the property intuit my thoughts? It sounds a bit fantastical, but after hearing about other skeptics’ experiences, I’m not so sure anymore.

But as with seasickness and combat, there’s no way to gauge in advance how you’ll fare until you’re in the thick of it. The only thing I know for sure is that I’m about to find out.

Russel Albert Daniels

• • •

Prior to my arrival at the ranch, the most unnerving thing I’d experienced was Brandon Fugal’s driving. He had picked me up that morning in Salt Lake City in his Lamborghini Urus Performante. Soon we were hurtling south on I-15 at 90 miles per hour to his airport hangar, while he expounded on his skepticism over TSA screenings and Covid-era face masks.

Halfway to Provo, he explains that he acquired Skinwalker Ranch as an “open-minded skeptic. I believed that there was most likely a natural explanation for all that had been reported. I had never seen a flying saucer or anything of the sort.” The Lambo touched 99 as he veered right to blow by a car dawdling along at 90.

Just like on the show, Fugal wore a fitted suit with a crisp, white dress shirt, fancy cowboy boots, and trademark wire-rim glasses—Harry Potter meets Gordon Gekko. He leans into the narrative arc of the hard-charging business icon: He says he started in real estate at age 18 and sold his first office a year later, works 16- to 20-hour days, and has since reshaped Salt Lake City’s skyline. He reveres Elon Musk and frequently name-drops rock stars and politicians in his orbit. (He hired the band Air Supply to play at his 2021 wedding.) Fugal describes himself as a 1980s teenager in a 50-year-old body, and boasts a vast collection of rare books and film memorabilia, including a full-size exoskeleton from the set of Terminator 2. And, most relevant to Skinwalker, he uses his fortune to underwrite certain science-driven moonshots.

Courtesy Jason Shook /The HISTORY Channel

In 2009, Cameron had just landed his brother’s private jet when, on a whim, Brandon asked him: How old is the technology and the physics behind this jet-propulsion system? The answer—the 1940s—shocked him. Fascinated by the question of how science had stalled in that realm, Brandon began researching alternative forms of propulsion, which led to a brief partnership with a former client, Joe Firmage, an early internet entrepreneur and UAP aficionado. Firmage claimed he was on the cusp of breakthrough technologies that enable purported UFOs to move in unorthodox and physics-defying ways. The project cratered, but in the aftermath Fugal was introduced to Robert Bigelow, a maverick billionaire who used his Las Vegas real-estate fortune to build a private aerospace firm. Bigelow Aerospace developed an expandable habitat for astronauts on the International Space Station before shuttering operations in 2020.

Bigelow, who has also espoused the presence of aliens and UAPs, is largely responsible for putting Skinwalker Ranch on the map. Established as an agricultural homestead in 1905, for more than a century the ranch experienced reports of strange activity, and as a result had been named for shape-shifting witches of Navajo lore. As early as 1911, a newspaper reported locals hearing “strange noises” emanating from the property, and a string of subsequent owners reported UAPs or other strange activity. Bigelow purchased it in 1996 from ranchers Terry and Gwen Sherman, who had been so spooked by their experiences there—which included UAP activity, cattle mysteriously slain, dire wolf–type creatures, and glowing orbs they say vaporized their dogs—that they eagerly unloaded the place.

Around the time he purchased the property, Bigelow founded and bankrolled the National Institute of Discovery Science, with the goal of conducting serious scientific study of UFOs and other paranormal activities at Skinwalker and beyond. He quickly installed a network of investigators who reported their own paranormal happenings at the ranch. A book written by chief investigator Colm Kelleher and news anchor George Knapp describes one incident in which something had disgorged the wiring within a closed-circuit ranch video camera while another camera, trained on it, captured no activity. The team produced another report detailing the 1998 killing of a perfectly healthy three-year-old cow. There were no signs of struggle and no tracks found, but the animal was missing its left eye and part of its left ear. Additionally, its heart was shredded, but its pericardium—the sac that encloses the organ and its major vessels—was intact.

Bigelow’s project later morphed into the Pentagon-funded Bigelow Aerospace Advanced Space Studies program. From 2008 to 2013, the program recorded more than 530 instances of paranormal activity witnessed by more than 150 people.

When Fugal met Bigelow in Las Vegas, he only knew what he’d read in Knapp and Kelleher’s book, and he told Bigelow he thought what had been seen at the ranch “was the product of groupthink mixed with misidentifying naturally occurring phenomena.”

By that point Fugal was leading the largest commercial real-estate enterprise in the intermountain west, with 30 offices in 11 states. He didn’t expect that alien sightings and disemboweled livestock would play well in his rarefied circles. “I did not want my name associated with these topics,” he says. But Fugal was intrigued, and after a series of lengthy conversations with Bigelow in 2016, he quietly bought the ranch for about $500,000 through a shell corporation called Adamantium Real Estate, named for the fictional alloy used to make Wolverine’s claws in Marvel Comics. Several days before the closing, he flew out to see the ranch for the first time and was stunned by the dramatic landscape: the high-desert mesa plateau, the snaking course of Dry Gulch Creek, the clutch of dilapidated pioneer homesteads evoking a complex history.

He’d been an Eagle Scout growing up and was now on the board of the Utah National Parks Council of the Boy Scouts of America. He figured he’d have a scientific team determine there was nothing untoward about the property, then he would donate it for scout camps and youth programs.

But before he could put that plan in motion, things started happening.

• • •

We settle into the main room of the Skinwalker Ranch headquarters, and the conversation naturally drifts toward the crew’s conversion stories, meaning the experiences that led them to believe that strange forces are afoot here.

Winterton, the ranch superintendent, grew up in the Uinta Basin, the geological feature that encompasses Skinwalker. His first time there—as a nonbelieving building inspector—he experienced severe vertigo and lightheadedness. “I finally had to back up against the wall and then I kind of slid down towards the floor,” he says.

None of these tellings is more compelling than Fugal’s. In 2016, an employee recorded a UFO sighting on his phone’s camera, snapping pictures of a horizontal object in the sky at a time when flight data showed there was no commercial or private air traffic over the ranch. The employee reported it to Fugal, who immediately began studying the images. Four months later, Fugal says he and two security guards saw a silver-gray spaceship-type object moving erratically above the mesa that borders the property.

And thus Fugal made the shift—in his words—“from being a healthy skeptic to an experiencer.” Since then, he has intensively pursued an understanding of what he describes as “high strangeness.” He erected a gate to seal off the property, installed a web of security cameras, and has poured millions of dollars into advanced technological instruments aimed at quantifying the ranch’s mysteries.

Erik Bard, an X-ray physicist, is one of the lead experts Fugal hired to harvest and interpret the reams of data these instruments have produced. Before moving to the ranch full-time, Bard was a partner in a firm that makes components for machines that produce or measure X-rays; many of its products go to the national labs, he says.

Bard has his own conversion story. He had dismissed what he’d heard about the ranch as “E.T. interdimensional religious whatever.” Then Fugal invited him to visit in October 2016—coincidentally, the same day that Fugal saw the UAP—and two things happened: On a trek out to the mesa, Bard pulled out his phone to take a picture and saw that the screen was flickering. At first, he thought he had broken it.

When he and others in his group returned to the homestead, Bard says he couldn’t keep his balance, and several others said they felt the ground spin. “The interesting thing is, I hadn’t told them that I was experiencing it,” he recalls.

Bard figured he’d try to make sense of these occurrences using science. First, he examined the phone malfunction. In an area with poor reception, a smartphone’s RF (radio frequency) components emit extra energy working to connect to a cell tower, which can interfere with other parts of the unit. Bard thought this was a perfectly good explanation, except that he couldn’t reproduce it. Several months later he tried a different experiment using a powerful rare-earth magnet capable of lifting 1,750 pounds of iron. When he put his phone on the edge of the magnet, he reproduced the effect.

The answer seemed to be the ranch’s unusual electromagnetic field, and specifically, a phenomenon called electromagnetic interference. In subsequent years, he and others have repeatedly dealt with more instances of what he experienced on his phone. Drones have mysteriously crashed; batteries on phones and other devices—ranging from boom microphones to H4n recorders—have suddenly drained. The ranch’s computer and surveillance systems have malfunctioned. These glitches haven’t just impacted the ranch’s equipment, Bard says, but also the equipment being brought in by outside experts.

Bard, who is more engaging and animated in person than on TV, read that strong magnetic fields also affect the human nervous system. MRI technicians, Bard explains, experience many of the same symptoms that people have at the ranch, including vertigo and nausea. These studies plus his benchtop experiment pointed to a magnetic field anomaly. “That was the beginning of trying to put a physics interpretation on some part of the phenomenon,” he says.

The source of the electromagnetic activity is another question: Bard speculates that it could be linked to some physics quirk in the space-time realm or something technological—a cloaked craft or UAP. Bard is still hunting for answers.



• • •

Bard’s super-magnet experiment is only one of the myriad scientific forays into the site, as the show’s viewers know well. It’s possible that no wild space in the country has been as closely scrutinized as this one. Just about everything across the landscape has been analyzed, poked, and sampled.

The crew has deployed hyperspectral imaging technology, which reveals light on parts of the spectrum humans can’t otherwise see. There are aircraft transponder data receivers; laboratory-grade thermographic imaging systems; advanced magnetometers; forward-looking infrared (FLIR) cameras, which detect infrared radiation and convert it to an image; and a geophone-based near-field seismometer, to ensure that no seismic wave goes undetected. Much of this tech is military-grade, Fugal says.

The team has mapped every inch of the ranch using a combination of LIDAR, drone-based photogrammetric mapping, and ground-penetrating radar. They’ve collected and analyzed samples using X-ray fluorescence. At one point, Bard and his crew brought in a team to aim high-powered optical lasers—devices colorfully known as a laser space cannons—at the sky above the ranch to search for more evidence of whatever invisible forces may hover overhead.

Curious findings keep the crew—and viewers—energized. Bard beckons me into the control room to show me what one of the simpler pieces of equipment—a surveillance camera stationed in Homestead 2—harvested. Feeds from the 50 or so audio-enabled security cameras across the property are available to Skinwalker Ranch Insiders, which is essentially a fan club. For a membership that starts at $8 a month, participants get access to “disturbing & anomalous audio, infrasonic, & frequency data,” according to the website. The more than 10,000 Insiders who have so far subscribed also get 24-hour access to the ranch webcams. Not only that, Bard has steampunked the system so that they are also able to control the cameras, and swivel them if they spot something. This has essentially created a community of volunteer citizen scientists. (“It’s like giving someone the keys to the International Space Station and being able to steer it around and position and explore the cosmos,” Fugal says.)

One Insider reported what Bard shows me now: At 1:39 a.m. one night, a door on Homestead 2 abruptly slammed shut. There was no wind, and no sign of anyone on camera. Played on repeat in grainy night-vision video, it’s undeniably creepy.

Russel Albert Daniels

• • •

It wasn’t always obvious that a TV show was the way to go. Fugal says after he was approached by the History channel in 2018, he only agreed to the show on three conditions: Nothing could be faked; the film crew had to use the investigators he’d hired; and his identity was to remain secret. The History Channel team agreed to the first two mandates—the show’s creators say that any staged reenactments are based on eyewitness accounts—but rejected the third, when the producers convinced him the research would only be believable if there was full transparency.

As it happened, the world was changing fast regarding perceptions of such phenomena—in particular, UAPs. Owing to a surge in military-pilot sightings, whistleblower pressure, and media coverage, UAPs were being legitimized in Congress and acknowledged more openly by the defense and intelligence communities, shifting the phenomena from the tinfoil-hat realm into the cultural mainstream.

In 2018, Fugal and his team, including three scientists, shared some of the data they’d collected with the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence and the Armed Services Committee in a confidential briefing in Washington, D.C. Fugal says he maintains contact with Utah’s senior senator, Mike Lee, and the state attorney general, Sean Reyes. “There has been a seismic shift in the way the government is approaching the topic,” he says.

But government knowledge is still largely blanketed in secrecy, and Bigelow’s findings on the ranch have similarly remained hidden from the public, even to Fugal; the program was secretly funded by the Pentagon, and its contents remain undisclosed. This is partly why he pivoted in the opposite direction. Everything his team learns is shared openly, he says, through the show or the phalanx of cameras, or both.

This was a canny move, to not only be transparent with what was going on there but to make transparency part of the point: Maybe you don’t believe in this, but you can believe in how we’re doing it. For a curious public starved by generations of government intransigence, this has been raw meat tossed to hungry wolves. “People want brutal honesty,” he says—and 2.22 million viewers tuned into the 2023–’24 season, making it the 10th most popular non-sports cable program.

Fugal says he’s never taken a penny for the show—that he’s given it all to charity and put it back into the ranch equipment. But he is clearly an adroit businessman with a nose for opportunity; soon after purchasing the ranch, he trademarked the name for purposes of the TV show and for use on merchandise such as T-shirts and mugs. The show has made him a celebrity—it “has turned my world upside down,” he says. He was even recognized on the street during a recent trip to France and Italy.

It’s clear he has fully shed any reservations he once harbored about serving as Skinwalker’s front man. On the show, he drops lines like “We’ll come to understand the dark forces that we’re interacting with, but also the nature of our world and our reality” without a hint of self-consciousness. He’s a rabid fan of 1980s science fiction; one of his prized possessions is a copy of the E.T. screenplay. What better way to feed that appetite than to hypothetically possess his own E.T.?

Fugal says he’s often asked what he believes they are dealing with. Could it be extraterrestrials? Multidimensional beings? Or some spiritual influence? “I answer it’s likely D: all of the above,” he says. The data they’ve collected over the years suggest there could be a wide range of origins and agendas associated with the phenomena. “The deeper the investigation digs both literally and figuratively,” he says, “the more complicated it becomes.”



• • •

By the time we wander out for a tour, the landscape is so dazzling I find it hard to muster much concern for my safety. The sky is vast and clear and the cottonwood trees are gilded in autumnal splendor. As we walk through and around the tumbledown homesteads, I pay particular attention to the largest of the three buildings that comprise Homestead 2—the site of the mysterious slamming door spotted by a Skinwalker Ranch Insider.

From the outside, the doorframe is dark and vacant, like a missing tooth; the modest two-room shack, now more than a century old, has gradually submitted to the forces of weather and age. Inside, leaves are scattered across the floorboards, and sunlight glides through the failing ceiling as if filtered through a julienne slicer. I see no evidence of wires that could have been rigged there to cause the sudden, unexplained movement. Gusts often cause doors to swing shut, but this one closed from the inside; the windows are empty cavities and there’s a hole in the roof, so there would be no way to build up any air pressure inside. The camera had shown the whole room, and nothing had moved prior to the door opening. “Look at the debris on the floor,” Fugal says. If it had been windy, leaves and other detritus would have been blowing everywhere.”

It’s fascinating, but there’s no way to make sense of it, and little time to linger. Moving around in Rhino-type vehicles used on the show, we cruise over to the “Triangle.” Investigators zeroed in on this patch of otherwise unremarkable land between the headquarters and the homesteads as a potential hotbed of paranormal activity during the show’s latter seasons after chronicling

unexplained interference with helicopter flights, drones, and other forms of aerial exploration.

The site consists of a set of jeep roads that form its geometric namesake, but we didn’t bother walking around; most of what makes the location interesting—at least for fans of the show—is invisible. The cast filled entire episodes with experiments that included elevating a squadron of drones and shooting rockets skyward to see if they could figure out what was occurring in the airspace above. These experiments have led the group to believe there may be some sort of interdimensional portal. It sounds far-fetched, but millions of viewers keep coming back for more.

Russel Albert Daniels

• • •

Cinematic as all of this is, what none of this technology has been able to provide so far is much in the way of concrete answers. The Secret of Skinwalker Ranch is a sumptuous buffet for conspiracy-driven UFOlogists and paranormal enthusiasts, unabashedly splicing supposition, folklore, and unexplained sightings with a series of high- and low-tech experiments. The result is a kind of true-believer cut-up, and viewers may feel they’ve learned a lot but have no clue what any of it amounts to.

Five seasons in, one question that emerges is whether a force intelligent enough to avoid detection, or reveal itself at will, can ever be identified. This plays into the producers’ hands, of course; a malevolent force that can reveal itself in opportune moments yet avoid detection drives the need for more investigations, and more television seasons. It creates a waves-against-the-shore rhythm, in which the cast experiences something, excitedly conducts a series of experiments—only to wind up, in some cases, with more questions than they had before. The tide advances and retreats, continually polishing the ranch’s legend in the process. But how long can they maintain the tension, and keep the audience entertained, while concrete answers remain just out of reach?

The next day, Fugal revs up another one of his toys—a Ferrari 488 Spider—for a final lunch meeting. Just before we leave the restaurant, I ask him something I’ve been pondering since he turned down my camping request: Will he even reopen the ranch to the public? Let us see for ourselves?

He shakes his head. Having a secure, living laboratory, he claims, will allow us to develop insights that could change the course of history. “I know that sounds like hyperbole, but you look at the topics we’re discussing, the implications,” he says, “if you don’t understand the weight and significance, then you perhaps are not… I think the appropriate way to say this is, you’re not ready.”

If the public at large is frustrated by this, they’re not showing it. Yes, there are some snarky reviews, but Fugal says he’s selling plenty of hats, DVDs, and T-shirts. The crew was about to start shooting a sixth season, and the series has spun off into Beyond Skinwalker Ranch, a History channel show that will probe other paranormal hotspots.

Maybe I’ll never be ready myself to grasp the significance of the site in the way that Fugal has. But my visit, in the end, did suggest one potential explanation for the enduring nature of this phenomenon. Maybe the real fantasy of Skinwalker Ranch isn’t that answers to the strange occurrences there will be identified, but that they were ever identifiable in the first place.

Here’s what I can report: I never felt dizzy or experienced any sudden pain. I did not exit the ranch anxious that I was being shadowed by some unknowable force, nor did my phone or digital recorder glitch. But I did feel something. It was the same thing I’d experienced coming off gigantic, twirl-you-upside-down amusement park rides—the ones where the caution signs are a little larger, and even though they’re for legal purposes, they add a fizz of danger. You know the sensation: You unbuckle and your hair is blown back and you feel buzzy from the thrill. Maybe, if you’re a fan of The Secret of Skinwalker Ranch, it’s the same feeling you have watching the show, in its best moments.

Are there really UFOs and dire wolves haunting this lonesome patch of high desert in eastern Utah? In the end, for millions of fans, the answer may not really matter.

Who Is The Winner Of MTV Dark Scroll?

title: Quantum Computing Explained : The Science, Security Risks and Global Race
description: Did you know that China has invested over $15 billion in quantum computing research? This staggering figure highlights the ...
article_content:
Did you know that China has invested over $15 billion in quantum computing research? This staggering figure highlights the intense global competition to lead in this groundbreaking technology. Quantum computing, which uses the unique properties of qubits, has the potential to solve problems that are currently beyond the reach of classical computers. However, this technological marvel also poses substantial security risks, particularly in encryption.

TL;DR Key Takeaways : Quantum computing leverages quantum physics for complex computations beyond classical computers.

IBM’s Quantum System 2 is a significant milestone, utilizing qubits that can exist in superposition.

Quantum computers use superposition and entanglement to solve complex problems instantaneously.

Potential applications include new material discovery, accelerated drug discovery, and advanced simulations.

Challenges include maintaining qubit stability and the need for extremely low temperatures.

The U.S. and China are leading the race in quantum computing with significant investments.

Quantum computing poses security risks to current encryption methods, prompting the development of quantum key distribution (QKD).

International collaboration is crucial but hindered by geopolitical tensions.

Quantum computing’s full potential is expected to be realized by 2033, impacting scientific discovery and global power dynamics.

Quantum computing has significant technological and geopolitical implications, with the potential to benefit all of humanity.

This groundbreaking technology promises to bring about significant advancements across various fields, from material science and drug discovery to cryptography and artificial intelligence. However, it also introduces substantial security risks, particularly in the realm of encryption. The race to develop quantum computing has become a focal point of international competition, with the United States and China leading the charge.

IBM’s Quantum Research Milestones

IBM’s research facility is at the forefront of quantum computing development, pushing the boundaries of what is possible with this innovative technology. The introduction of the IBM Quantum System 2 marks a significant milestone in the field, bringing us closer to realizing the full potential of quantum computing. Central to this technology are quantum bits, or qubits, which are the building blocks of quantum computers. Unlike classical bits, which can only exist in a state of either 0 or 1, qubits can exist in a state of superposition, meaning they can be both 0 and 1 simultaneously. This remarkable property allows quantum computers to process vast amounts of data at unprecedented speeds, tackling complex problems that would take classical computers centuries to solve.

Core Principles of Quantum Computing

The fundamental difference between classical bits and qubits lies in their quantum mechanical nature. While classical computers use bits to perform calculations sequentially, quantum computers use the principles of quantum mechanics, such as superposition and entanglement, to solve complex problems in a fraction of the time. Entanglement is a phenomenon where two or more qubits become correlated in such a way that their states are dependent on each other, regardless of the distance between them. This alignment with the quantum mechanical nature of the universe enables quantum computers to tackle problems that are currently unsolvable by classical means, opening up new frontiers in scientific discovery and technological advancement.

Quantum computers use superposition and entanglement to solve complex problems

Qubits can exist in multiple states simultaneously, unlike classical bits

Quantum computing aligns with the quantum mechanical nature of the universe

Quantum Computing Explained

Here are a selection of other articles from our extensive library of content you may find of interest on the subject of Quantum computing :

Transformative Applications

Quantum computing holds the potential to transform various fields, from material science and drug discovery to cryptography and artificial intelligence. In the field of material science, quantum computers can simulate the behavior of complex molecules and materials at an unprecedented level of accuracy, leading to the discovery of new materials with unique properties that could have far-reaching implications for industries such as energy, electronics, and aerospace. In the realm of medicine, quantum simulations can accelerate the process of drug discovery by accurately modeling the interactions between molecules and proteins, allowing the development of targeted therapies for diseases that have long eluded conventional treatments. Additionally, quantum computers can simulate the behavior of atoms and subatomic particles, providing insights into the fundamental nature of the universe and allowing the design of advanced materials and pharmaceuticals.

Quantum computing can transform material science, drug discovery, and fundamental physics

Quantum simulations can accurately model molecular interactions and accelerate drug development

Quantum computers can provide insights into the fundamental nature of the universe

Challenges and Limitations

Despite its immense promise, quantum computing faces significant challenges that must be overcome before it can reach its full potential. One of the biggest challenges is maintaining qubits in a stable state, as they are highly susceptible to environmental disturbances such as temperature fluctuations, electromagnetic interference, and even vibrations. To preserve the delicate quantum states necessary for computation, qubits must be kept at extremely low temperatures, close to absolute zero, which requires sophisticated cooling systems and shielding. Additionally, quantum computers are not yet outperforming classical supercomputers in practical applications, highlighting the need for further advancements in quantum stability, error correction, and scalability.

Maintaining qubits in a stable state is a significant challenge

Qubits must be kept at extremely low temperatures to preserve quantum states

Further advancements in quantum stability, error correction, and scalability are needed

Global Competition and Investments

The race to develop quantum computing is intensifying, with the United States and China at the forefront of this global competition. Both nations have made significant investments in quantum research and development, recognizing the strategic importance of leading in this transformative technology. China has committed over $15 billion to quantum research, demonstrating its determination to become a dominant player in the field. The United States has also made substantial investments, with government agencies such as the Department of Energy and the National Science Foundation funding numerous quantum research projects. The strategic importance of leading in quantum technology cannot be overstated, as it has significant implications for national security, economic competitiveness, and scientific advancement.

Security Risks and Mitigations

While quantum computing holds immense potential for scientific and technological advancement, it also poses substantial security risks, particularly in the realm of encryption. Quantum computers have the potential to decrypt current internet encryption methods, which rely on the difficulty of factoring large numbers. This poses a significant threat to the security of financial systems, sensitive data, and national security. To mitigate these risks, researchers are developing new encryption methods that are resistant to quantum attacks, such as quantum key distribution (QKD). QKD uses the principles of quantum mechanics to create unbreakable encryption keys, ensuring the security of data even in the face of quantum computing advancements.

Collaborative Efforts and Ecosystem Development

IBM is actively collaborating with other tech companies, research institutions, and government agencies to advance the field of quantum computing. However, collaboration with Chinese companies is limited due to national security concerns and geopolitical tensions. International collaboration is crucial for the progress of quantum research, as it enables the sharing of knowledge, resources, and expertise. The development of a robust quantum ecosystem requires cooperation and knowledge sharing across borders, fostering innovation and accelerating the pace of discovery. However, geopolitical tensions and competing national interests can hinder these collaborative efforts, underscoring the need for diplomacy and international cooperation in the pursuit of quantum computing advancements.

Future Outlook and Predictions

Predictions suggest that the full potential of quantum computing will be realized by 2033, ushering in a new era of scientific discovery and technological innovation. As quantum technology advances, new encryption methods will be necessary to safeguard against the threat of quantum decryption. The broader impact of quantum computing on scientific discovery and global power dynamics is profound, with the potential to reshape industries, transform economies, and alter the balance of power on the global stage. Quantum advancements have the potential to benefit all of humanity, driving progress in fields such as healthcare, energy, and environmental sustainability, while also fostering global cooperation and understanding.

Technological and Geopolitical Implications

Quantum computing embodies a dual nature as both a scientific tool and a strategic asset, with significant technological and geopolitical implications. The development of quantum computing is not only a scientific endeavor but also a matter of national security and economic competitiveness. International collaboration is essential to harness the full potential of quantum computing, but geopolitical tensions and competing national interests pose risks to progress. Despite these challenges, the optimistic view is that quantum computing advancements will ultimately benefit all of humanity, driving innovation, fostering global cooperation, and ushering in a new era of scientific discovery and technological progress. As we stand on the cusp of this quantum revolution, it is imperative that we navigate the challenges and opportunities with wisdom, foresight, and a commitment to the greater good of all.

Media Credit: Bloomberg Originals

title: 32,000-year-old mummified woolly rhino half-eaten by predators unearthed in Siberia
description: Researchers found the carcass in August 2020 in Russia's Sakha Republic, and the discovery has revealed a never-before-seen ...
article_content:
Scientists have discovered the deep-frozen, mummified carcass of a young woolly rhinoceros in Siberia's ice that was feasted on by predators tens of thousands of years ago.

The woolly rhino's right side is well preserved, with patches of skin and fur that have stayed intact over millennia, but its left side shows the youngster was mauled in the hours preceding or following its death.

"From the upper part of the thigh to the level of the shoulder blade, [the carcass] is severely destroyed," researchers from the Russian Academy of Sciences and the Academy of Sciences of the Republic of Sakha wrote in a study documenting the carcass, published July 1 in the journal Doklady Earth Sciences . "The internal cavity of the body is exposed, and most of the intestines are missing."

From the mangled carcass, "it is obvious that the left side of the mummy was eaten by predators," the researchers wrote. Remains of tiny crustaceans embedded in the fur also indicate the woolly rhino (Coelodonta antiquitatis) died in a shallow pool of water, the team noted.

Radiocarbon dating suggests the young woolly rhino died and froze more than 32,000 years ago.

Woolly rhinos roamed the Arctic tundra between 460,000 and 12,000 years ago , during the last ice age . They were huge beasts and the second largest herbivores in the mammoth steppe ecosystem after woolly mammoths (Mammuthus primigenius). Like mammoths, woolly rhinos were well-adapted to the cold climate thanks to their coat of shaggy fur — but scientists still know very little about these prehistoric animals, according to the study.

Related: 'Closer than people think': Woolly mammoth 'de-extinction' is nearing reality — and we have no idea what happens next

Sign up for the Live Science daily newsletter now Get the world’s most fascinating discoveries delivered straight to your inbox. Contact me with news and offers from other Future brands Receive email from us on behalf of our trusted partners or sponsors

The rare discovery of a near-intact woolly rhino has helped researchers fill some of those gaps.

Scientists excavated the carcass in August 2020 from the ice-covered banks of the Tirekhtyakh River in Russia's northeastern Sakha Republic. They dubbed the animal "Abyisky rhinoceros" after the local district and sent its remains to the Academy of Sciences of the Republic of Sakha, where the carcass currently sits in a freezer.

For the new study, researchers temporarily defrosted the carcass and took samples of skin, fur and soft tissue for analysis. They also examined the woolly rhino's teeth, measured the length of one of its horns and noted the size of a large hump on its back, which appeared to be filled with fat.

Illustration of a woolly rhinoceros (Coelodonta antiquitatis). (Image credit: De Agostini via Getty Images)

The horn was 9.4 inches (24 centimeters) long and presented three to four dark patches that typically correspond to the number of years lived by a rhinoceros, according to the study. The height at the shoulder of the carcass was close to 4.3 feet (130 cm). Together, this indicates the woolly rhino was 4 to 4.5 years old when it died and hadn't reached sexual maturity.

Its fur was darker than that of a smaller woolly rhino calf discovered in 2014 in the same district. That calf, named "Sasha," was frozen for at least 10,000 years and covered in thin, almost-blond hair . In contrast, adult woolly rhinos that were previously pulled from the ice have coarse, dark brown fur.

"The fur of the Abyisky rhinoceros has a uniform light brown color due to the combination of white, beige, and brown hair," the researchers wrote in the study. "The coat is darker on the ears and feet and lighter on the back, belly, and hind legs."

Remarkably, the Abyisky rhinoceros also had a 5-inch-high (13 cm) hump filled with fatty mass on its back, the likes of which scientists had never seen on a woolly rhino carcass. Fatty humps are relatively common in Arctic animals, Love Dalén , a professor of evolutionary genomics at Stockholm University in Sweden who was not involved in the study, told CNN . They evolved to beat the cold and store energy for when times get tough, he said.

The newly discovered 4-year-old appears to represent an intermediate stage of woolly rhino development. Specimens with preserved tissues like this one are invaluable for further research, and particularly for genetic tests that cannot be done on bones, Dalén said.
